attributes.title: Investigating the mechanism of wearable camera memory support

q1.value: Wearable camera-cued recall of naturalistic events in young and older adults: encoding-retrieval match

q3.value:
Wearable cameras can be used to improve memory for recent experiences, but at present little is understood about how the technology interacts with human memory. Despite promising early results, this lack of knowledge precludes directed improvement of technological memory supports.

Key points: 
- Wearable cameras typically capture around 300-400 still photographs per hour
- Photos are captured automatically, from the wearer's perspective, and are later reviewed as a time-compressed sequence of cues to aid memory retrieval

This study aims to investigate how photos from wearable cameras cue retrieval of episodic memory, within the context of existing knowledge derived from the laboratory study of memory. Specifically, this study investigates whether a reduced-length sequence of photos constitutes a cue discriminative enough to support recall as effectively as a full-length sequence of photos. 

Participants will complete an encoding activity, which consists of two self-guided tours of local areas, using a tour booklet designed by the experimenter. All participants will complete both tours - one outdoors, and one inside a museum. Each tour consists of ten stops, and at each stop the participant must answer a question by finding relevant information in the environment, and must read a fact related to the location, which is provided in the tour booklet. During this encoding activity a wearable camera will be worn, which captures still images at a rate of 1 per 10s, from the perspective of the wearer.

After a retention interval of 2 weeks, participants will be asked to freely recall each of the two tours, following which they will be presented with images from their wearable camera - a full set of images for one tour, and a reduced set for the other tour - and asked to report any further memory details prompted by review of the photographs.

q4.value:
H1: Healthy older adults will exhibit a quantitative memory deficit relative to healthy young adults at baseline (one-tailed)

H2: Recall cued by a full set of photographs will be quantitatively different from recall cued by a subset of photographs (two tailed)

H3: The number of photographs available in the sequence will affect young and older adults' recall differently

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Mixed design with two factors: age group (young vs. old) and cue sequence (full vs. reduced). Age group is an observed variable; cue sequence is a within-subjects variable.

The dependent variable is the number of details recalled about each tour. Memories will be reported in free narrative form, and will be coded for number of details by the experimenter and an additional coder. Reliability between the experimenter and additional coder will be calculated. 

Four memories will be measured: baseline recall for each tour (before seeing any photographs) and photo-cued recall for each tour. Photo-cued recall will be taken as the baseline recall plus any new details recalled after seeing the photographs of each tour.

q9.value: This study does not involve randomisation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Young adult participants (age 18-35) will be recruited from a database of predominantly university students who either must participate for course credit, or who have signed up to voluntarily participate for money. Older adult participants (age 65+) will be recruited from a database of individuals who previously responded to an advert expressing an interest in participating in psychology studies. Participants will be paid £25 for completing the study, with the possible exception of some younger adults who may choose to receive course credit instead. 

All participants will be physically mobile, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision, and will be fluent English speakers without language impairment. Older participants will be screened for dementia using the Addenbrooke's Cognitive Examination III.

q13.value: The target sample size is 48 (24 young adults and 24 older adults). If there is attrition, further participants will be recruited ad hoc until the target is reached.

q14.value:
This is an applied research question, and consequently I am looking primarily for large effects that would be noticeable to the user of the wearable camera. In each study, the design is a mixed 2 (age group: young vs. old, between subs) x 2 (cue type: full vs. reduced, within subs), and the minimum effect size of interest is d=0.5, equivalent to f=0.25 (Cohen, 1988). G*Power a priori sample size calculation using f=0.25, alpha level of 0.05, and required power of 90% indicates that a total sample size of 46 should be sufficient to detect the within-subjects effect. The between-group differences (i.e., age effects) are expected to be larger – previous research using a similar design suggests d=1.00 – 1.20, therefore the planned sample size should be able to detect similar age effects with 97% power. 

One additional participant will be recruited to each group to allow for adequate counterbalancing of tour order during the encoding session and tour venue/cue sequence combinations.

question.value:
The retrieval cue will be manipulated as follows: 

- Full photo set: all photos captured by the wearable camera will be presented to participants.
- Reduced photo set: a subset of photos will be presented to participants. The subset will comprise one photograph from each of 10 locations visited by the participant during the encoding activity. If there is a choice of more than one photograph captured at the target location, the precise photograph will be chosen by the experimenter as the one which shows the target the most clearly, and which does not depict other non-target material (such as the tour booklet) except where unavoidable.

The outcome measure will be the number of details recalled by the participant. This will be measured at baseline (i.e., before seeing any photos) and under each cue condition (after seeing a full photo-set for one tour, and after seeing a reduced photo-set for the other tour). 

Participants will be asked to report their memories in narrative form, and their responses will be audio-recorded and transcribed. Transcripts will then be coded for the number of details of different types following steps 2 and 3 in the attached coding protocol.

For the two post-cue retrieval attempts, only "new" details will be counted (i.e., those that were not reported during the baseline attempt) and the total memory score for cued memories will be taken to be the baseline score for that activity plus the additional "new" details that are reported post-cue.

The number of details recalled about each activity will be tallied for each participant, such that each participant will receive four scores: two baseline recall scores: number of details recalled for each activity prior to reviewing any photographs, and two post-cued scores: number of new details recalled when a full photo-set was presented, and number of new details recalled when a reduced photo-set was presented. Cued recall scores will be the sum of the baseline recall plus new details for the given tour.

Data will be analysed in a 2 x 2 mixed ANOVA. Cue type (full vs. reduced) will be entered as a repeated measures variable, and age group will be entered as a between-subjects variable. We will look for main effects of both age group and cue type, and an interaction between age group and cue type. Both frequentist and Bayesian statistics will be reported. For the Bayesian analysis, we will use the default settings in JASP, and will not specify directional assumptions for the main effect of cue type, but will specify a prior hypothesis for the main effect of age, namely that young adults will outperform older adults. We do not have any prior about the interaction effect.

q21.value: We will use an alpha of 0.05 for the frequentist statistics, and Bayes factors of 3 (or 1/3) for the Bayesian analyses. In the frequentist analyses we will establish whether the findings are statistically significant with the regard to the specified alpha. In the Bayesian analyses we will assess the strength of the evidence given the computed Bayes factors.

q22.value: Data will only be excluded on the basis of failed screening tests in the older adults, or where participants failed to follow the instructions on the guided tour.

q23.value: Data will be collected in a single face-to-face session, so there will not be any missing data for the main variable of interest (i.e., number of details recalled). If any screening test or other peripheral data are lost, this will be reported but will not affect our handling of the data relating to the main variable of interest.

q24.value: We will explore the subdivision of the total number of details recalled into those that are central to, and peripheral to, the event.

attributes.title: Genderspecific attitudes towards homo- and bisexuals

q1.value: Genderspecific attitudes of heterosexuals towards homo- and bisexuals

q3.value: The study aims to show gender specific differences of heterosexual people concerning their attitudes and assumptions towards homosexual and bisexual people.

q4.value:
1.	Men show higher homo- and binegativity than women.
2.	Bigger negativity is shown towards bisexuals than homosexuals. 
3.	Men have more negative attitudes towards men than women.
4.	Women have more negative attitudes towards bisexual than homosexual people.
5.	Bisexuals are rated as more promiscuous than homosexuals. 
6.	Bisexuality is seen as less stable in terms of sexual orientation than homosexuality. 
7.	Bisexual women are rather rated as “truly heterosexual” whereas bisexual men are 
        rather rated as “truly gay”.
8.	Bisexuality is more often seen as socialized than homosexuality.
9.	If there is the assumption, that the sexual orientation is socialized, there is bigger homo- 
        and binegativity.
10.	Men are more afraid than women of being perceived as homosexual.
11.	If there is bigger fear of being perceived as homosexual, there is bigger homo- and 
        binegativity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Mixed design with 1 within factor (sexual orientation of target) and 2 levels (homosexual and bisexual) and 2 between factors (gender of subject and gender of target) with each 2 levels (male and female)

q9.value: Each participant is assigned to eather judge female (homosexual and bisexual) or male (homosexual and bisexual) targets. Furthermore the order of questions concerning homonegativity resp. binegativity are randomized between participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: No analysis happened yet, just checking of the gender distribution of participants to make sure to adjust the preferably representative sample (as much men as women as participants).

question.value: Participants will be recruited through groups in social media and direct approach. They have the chance to win one of 3 coupons. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants in a preferably balanced ratio of men and women. Consequently we aim to have at least 70 participants in each group (2 subject groups (women and men) rating 2 target groups (women and men))

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a medium effect size of .4 (differs in between hypothesis) at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We measure homonegativity and binegativity, assumed promiscuity, stability of sexual orientation, assumptions about the "true" sexual orientation of bisexuals as well as about genetic or socialised reasons of being homo- or bisexual and fear of being perceived as homosexual oneself (on a scale of 1-7, being 1 "I don't agree at all", 4 "neither nor", 7 "I totally agree"). Furthermore we measure social desirability (with yes or no as possible answers). 
Besides we ask for demographic data as age, highest educational achievement, profession, gender, cisgender and sexual orientation.
For conducting the t-tests we will use the means of every scale (homo- and binegativity, promiscuity, stability, "true" sexual orientation, socialised origins, fear). Furthermore we'll use ANOVAs.

H1-H4: We will conduct 2-samples-t-tests for independent samples (gender of subject as between factor) for Hypothesis 1, 3 and 4. For Hypothesis 2 we will use a 2-samples-t-test for dependent samples (sexual orientation of target as within factor). 
Also for the condition “finding no difference in men concerning their assessment of homosexuality vs. bisexuality” resp. “finding no difference in women concerning their assessment of men vs. women” we will conduct t-tests for dependent samples.  
Moreover the supposed mean differences will be tested in an ANOVA with gender of subject and gender of target as between subject factors and sexual orientation as within subject factor and negativity as dependent variable. 

H5, H6, H8: We will conduct 2-samples-t-tests for dependent samples for hypothesis 5, 6 and 8 and mixed ANOVAs.

H7: We will conduct 2-samples-t-tests for independent samples and we’ll compare mean differences in “truly hetero” and “truly gay” between the two conditions (male and female) and mixed ANOVAs.

H9, H11: We will measure the correlation between the assumption “socialized” and negativity (H9) as well as fear of being gay and negativity by calculating person’s correlation and fisher’s z. We will also calculate the correlation between placement in right part of the political spectrum and negativity as well as fear.

H10: We will conduct 2-samples-t-tests for independent samples and mixed ANOVAs.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: In terms of biographic data we will exclude participants who don't define themselves as men or women, and who are not cisgender. Also we will exclude people who state that they are not heterosexual as well as participants, who don't agree to utilization of their data or tick, that they haven't filled out the survey seriously.

q25.value:

attributes.title: The configuration of imagination and visual memory

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The configuration of imagination and visual memory

other.value:
Questionnaires investigating object visual imagery (Marks, 1976), spatial and object imagery (Blazhenkova, 2016), mathematical proficiency and creativity (Kaufman, Cole, & Baer, 2009) will be administered.  These will be correlated with performance of the main variables. However, this data is also being collected so that it can be combined with similar measures from these scales collected in other experiments with other measures of the main DVs listed above. Thus, they are not the main focus of this experiment. 

Strategy questions will be administered once participants have completed the imagination and sequential working memory task in order to understand what strategies participants used during the tasks. See questions for each task below.

Imagination task

Participants rate each statement using a (5 point) scale that ranges from fully disagree to fully agree for questions 1 to 7. Question 8 requires participants to insert text. 
1)	After the cues were presented, I used them as I was asked to.
2)	I often did not imagine the objects.
3)	When tested I remembered the arrow cues instead of thinking about the imagined objects.
4)	I used words and/or sentences to help myself remember.
5)	I used numbers to help myself remember.
6)	After the cues I vividly imagined the object, as if I could see it in front of me.
7)	The arrows made it possible for me to know which cell I were to imagine the object in.
8)	Please describe the strategy used to complete the task. Please be as explicit as possible when answering this question.

Sequential Working Memory Task

Question 1 requires participants to insert text.
1)	Please describe the strategy used to complete the task. Please be as explicit as possible when answering this question.

sample.value:
A priori power analysis indicated 28 participants in the current experiment to have a 99% power for detecting a large sized effect. The sample size was determined using .05 significance level (two tailed), and was based on 42 participants from Atkin, Guest, Howard, Baguley and Baker (in preperation) using the most suitable effect of interest (effect size =.85 and correlation = .52 were determinded from the performance (d’) data between imagination set-size 5 and visual working memory set-size 5). 

For all tasks, participants will complete 36 trials at each test presentation conditions (whole display, single post-cue display and single cue display) equally distributed across 3 main blocks. Of the 36 trials, 18 trials will constitute identical test array presentations (i.e. test display is identical to initially cued locations) and 18 will constitute different test array presentations. Within each of the identical/different presentation types, 9 trials will be presented to the left of the display and the other 9 trials will be presented to the right of the display.

analyses.value:
Hypotheses a) and b) the DV s will be analysed using a repeated measures ANOVA (3 (Task: imagination/VWM/VSTM) x 3 (Test display: whole, single post-cue, single-cue) with appropriate post hoc t-tests (Bonferroni adjustment) carried out if there are significant interactions.

Hypothesis c) the DV s will be analysed using Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

outliers.value: Data will be trimmed to exclude responses that were too fast (<300ms) or too slow (>6000ms) for all tasks. Data trimming limits are deemed acceptable to eliminate trials in which participants might not be attending to the task sufficiently. Data will also be trimmed where participants response time (RT) is more than 2 standard deviations above their mean RT.

dependent.value: The DVs will be proportion correct, the false alarm rate, hit rate and d’. Vividness ratings and response time will also be recorded.

conditions.value:
A repeated-measures design will be used.

For all tasks, the effects of test presentation (whole display, single post-cue display and single cue display) on the DVs will be examined. Therefore participants will be assigned to three conditions (whole display, single post-cue display and single cue display) in the imagination task, three conditions (whole display, single post-cue display and single cue display) in the visual working memory task and three conditions (whole display, single post-cue display and single cue display) in the visual short-term memory task.

hypothesis.value:
Previous research found that the number of items that can be maintained in imagination is severely capacity limited, and its capacity is lower than that of working memory (Atkin, Guest, Howard, Baguley & Baker, in preparation). However, little is known about how information is configured in imagination and visual memory and how this can affect performance.
The aim of this study is:

a)	To investigate how the configuration of visual information influences subsequent performance in a test of the veracity of imagination and visual memory.
 
To do this we will run three tasks investigating imagination, visual working memory and visual short-term memory. All tasks use the same 6 by 6 grid in each trial, in which the gridlines are grey and the background white.

Task 1: An Imagination task in which an arrow on the column and an arrow on the row of the grid indicates that participants have to imagine that the square at the intersection of these arrow cues is black. The imagination of the participant is built up gradually from 0 locations to 5 locations being imagined to be black, this is done sequentially so that every 2 seconds, the arrow cues designate a location to be imagined as black. This is repeated for until the set size has been reached (here 5 locations). The grid is presented on one side of the screen. Participants are then tested on their imagination by being presented with a grid on the other side of the screen within which a test display will be presented. There will be three types of test display: all five black squares (whole display), all five black squares with one square highlighted white (single post-cue display) or a single black square (single cue display). Participants are asked to judge whether all of these squares (whole display) or the cued square was originally cued or not. On half the trials the test display will be the originally cued squares, and in the other half it will differ such that one square is in a different location. 

Task 2: A visual working memory (VWM) task using the same grids as in Task 1, but where the to-be remembered squares are shown as filled in at each stage. The image is built up sequentially as per Task 1, with a different square being shown as filled every 2s until the set size is reached (here 5 locations). The grid is then masked.  Participants are tested as in Task 1.

Task 3: A simultaneous visual short-term memory (VSTM). In this task there is not a sequential build-up of the stimulus. Rather the stimulus is shown briefly with all the grid locations (here set size 5) shown as filled. The grid is then masked.  Participants are then tested as in Task 1.

In tasks 1 and 2, participants are asked to build up their working memory or imagination sequentially with grid locations being added at each step. In task 3, participants are presented with a single stimulus in which all the five grid locations are already blacked out. Previously Atkin et al. (in preparation) have used whole display and single post-cue display at test, and so the purpose of the study is to explore performance differences when using these different types of test. Note that while Atkin et al. manipulated set size, only a set size of 5 will be used here, as the focus of the tasks is not on set size effects but on how methodological differences could alter performance in the memory and imagination tasks. 


It is hypothesised that:

a)	Based on previous findings, performance will be higher in the simultaneous visual short-term memory task than the sequential working memory task.

b)	There will be an effect of display type on performance between tasks. In the simultaneous visual short-term memory task performance will be greater in the single post-cue condition than the whole display condition. Specifically, although the global organisation is the same between the two conditions (due to five squares always being presented at test), a single post-cue condition advantage is expected because decision factors only apply to one item, whereas in the whole display condition, decision factors apply for each item. In addition, performance in the whole display condition will be greater than the single cue condition. Specifically, the whole display condition advantage is expected because the global organisation is re-presented at test, unlike the single cue condition where the global organisation is not re-presented at test. Thus, the global configuration can assist performance in the whole display condition. Similarly, the sequential working memory task conditions will benefit in the same way as the simultaneous visual short-term memory task. For imagination it is unclear as to how performance will differ across the different types of test display.

c)	Performance in each of the three tasks will strongly correlate (positively) with one another, with the strongest relationship predicted between the imagination task and the sequential working memory task.

attributes.title: Probing the Nature of Same vs. Different Category Concepts

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Probing the Nature of Same Vs. Different Category Concepts

other.value: For secondary analyses, we will conduct Bonferroni-correct pairwise comparisons between trial types (target present and target absent separately) if there is a significant interaction in the behavioral analyses, and among all trial types for the EEG analyses.

sample.value: Based on previous studies and power analyses, we will include 20 younger adults in the EEG study.

analyses.value:
For the behavioral data, we will be running a 2 (category: Same v. Different) x 2 (trial type: Exemplar vs. Category) ANOVA on target present trials for reaction times and accuracy separately. For target absent trials, we will conduct a 2 (category: Same v. Different) x 3 (trial type: Foil, No Target Exemplar, No Target Category) ANOVA reaction times and accuracy separately.

For the EEG data, we will conduct a 3 (trial type) x 2 (category) ANOVA on the mean amplitude from 200-300ms.

outliers.value: As is typical in EEG studies, we will exclude data sets that have excessive eye movements (>50% of trials excluded due to eye-movements) and poor accuracy (< 50% accuracy). Noisy electrodes (due to equipment failure) that are not included in the final EEG analyses will be manually excluded.

dependent.value: We will measure reaction time and accuracy based on behavioral responses to key presses to target present and target absent trials. We will also measure the N2pc component at PO7 and PO8 electrodes, at 200-300ms.

conditions.value: All participants will complete 4 conditions- Sky Exemplar, Ground Exemplar, Same Category, and Different Category searches.

hypothesis.value:
Is identifying pairs of objects from a conceptually same category such as sky-associated objects (cloud, bird, etc.) or ground-associated objects (tree, flower, etc.) a more primitive, and therefore more efficient, task than identifying pairs of objects from conceptually different categories (sky and ground)?

We will compare behavioral and neural (EEG, N2pc) measures between pairs of conceptually same and different categories in younger adults.

attributes.title: How Episodic Foresight Develops: The Role of Executive Functions and Motivation

q1.value: How Episodic Foresight Develops: The Role of Executive Functions and Motivation

q2.value: Jessica Marks, Prof. Dr. Silvia Schneider, Dr. Babett Voigt

q3.value:
Episodic foresight, accordingly the ability to mentally simulate future events and to use such imagination to guide current behavior, is crucial for everyday life functioning. Therefore, it is  important to understand the emergence and the development of episodic foresight. 
Empirically, evidence of the emergence of episodic foresight development varies between studies. In particular the underlying mechanisms and the criticial contextual factors that drive those age-dependent differences remain largely unknown. 
Though, the developmental framework of episodic foresight development proposes that age-related differences in the development of episodic foresight partly result from the maturation of executive functions. While the framework of executive functions postulates the 'hot' and the 'cool' type of executive processes wich depend on the motivational context of an event. 
The episodic foresight procedure that will be used for this project bases on Suddendorf and colleagues (e.g. Redshaw & Suddendorf, 2013; Suddendorf et al., 2011). The setting involves a training area and two main areas: the 'present area' and the 'future area'. The paradigm is based on a problem solving task followed by a choice task. The problem will be presented to the participants in the future area. It involves a container that just can be opened with one particular key, which will not be available in the future area at this point. Afterwards a delay period and the presentation of the same problem in the present area follows. Then the
children will be required to select one of three presented keys to take back to the future area. Only one key, however, will be suitable to solve the problem. A future-oriented action
will be defined as choosing the right object for the right reason and / or right application. 
In order to manipulate children's motivation to solve the future problem, the different containers include toys of varying topics and varying quantity. We will also manipulate the current desire of the participants by varying the locking of these containers and by varying the rationale of the item choice between conditions and two experiments. In Experiment 1 the current desire is different from, but compatible with the upcoming need whereas in Experiment 2 children's current desire is in conflict with fulfilling the upcoming need. In both experiments, we will assess 'hot' and 'cool' executive functions following the episodic foresight task. 
To sum up, this project examines in two experiments whether differences in episodic foresight between three to five year old children are driven by ('hot' and 'cool') executive functions and also whether the time of emergence of episodic foresight development depends on the motivational significance of the context.

q4.value:
Research Question 1: Do age-related differences in 'cool' and 'hot' executive function explain why younger preschool children have lower skills in episodic foresight compared to older preschool children?

H1: Age-related differences in 'hot' and 'cool' executive functions explain age-related differences in episodic foresight. 

Research Question 2: Do children's motivation for a future episode and children's current desires affect the relative role of 'hot' executive functions for age-related differences in episodic foresight?

H2: Age-related differences in 'hot' executive functions should more strongly predict age-related differences in episodic foresight, if children head to or are in a motivational significant state, compared to conditions in which children head to or are in a neutral motivational state. 

Research Question 3: How does children's motivation for a future episode influence whether episodic foresight emerges early versus late during preschool years?

H3a: The hot/cool framework predicts a protracted emergence for episodic foresight for events of high personal importance compared to events of less importance. 
H3b: In contrast, the dual competition model suggests a more accelerated emergence under these conditions. 
We will contrast both predictions. 

Research Question 4: How do different types of current motivational states influence whether episodic foresight emerges early versus late during preschool years?

H4a: The hot/cool framework and the dual competition model uniformly predict protracted emergence of episodic foresight, if children hold a current desire while thinking about the future. 
H4b: In contrast, developmental accounts on desire reasoning also propose a decelerated emergence of episodic foresight, but only if current and future motivational perspective are dependent and mutually exclusive, rather than merely different. 
We will contrast both predictions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The project comprises two experiments with two independent samples. The setting is identical for both experiments, except for the desire condtion (see below). 

We will use a between-subject design wherein the participants will be randomly assigned
to the motivational condition (high and low motivation) as well as to the desire condition (experiment 1: neutral and compatible; experiment 2: neutral and conflict). 

Age group will be a between-subjects factor with three levels: 3 year-old (3;0-3;11) , 4 year-old (4;0-4;11), 5 year-old (5;0-5;11).

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via an already established databank of families who are interested in participating in developmental studies in our lab. 

Parents will  receive 5€ for their time and children will receive small presents worth 5€ for participating. 

Participants will be between 3 and 5 years, born full-term and do not have a history of major medical problems or developmental disorders according to parent report.

q13.value:
Our target sample size is 544, therefore we will recruit 272 participants for each experiment (Experiment 1 and Experiment 2). 

Thereby in both experiments we will have 96 participants per age-group (3 year-old, 4 year-old and 5 year-old) and 24 participants for each of the 4 conditions. 

We will attempt to recruit up to 640 participants, assuming that not all will complete the total task or numerous data points will likely need to be excluded.

q14.value:
A simulation study by Preacher and colleagues (2007)  showed that a sample size of N=200 would allow to detect small moderated mediation effect, i.e. a beta of .14 with a power of 65% and medium-sized effects of beta = .39 with a power of 100%. 
In this project we will use dichotomous dependent variables, hence the required sample size will exceed the suggestions of Preacher and colleagues (2007). Analyses with dichotomous variables require about 36% larger samples to achieve the same statistical power that would be found for continuous variables (MacCallum et al., 2002). 
Therefore our target sample size is N = 272 children for each of the two experiments. Assuming that not all will complete the total task or numerous data points will likely need to be excluded, we expect to recruit N = 320 children for each experiment.

question.value:
We will recruit at three levels of the age variable: 3 year-old (3;0-3;11) , 4 year-old (4;0-4;11), 5 year-old (5;0-5;11). 

In order to manipulate children's motivation to solve the future problem, the container includes toys of varying topics and varying quantity. Thus, we will manipulate the motivational condition. The two levels of this variable are termed high vs. low.

In addition we manipulate children's current desire (Experiment 1: neutral desire condition vs. compatible desire condition; Experiment 2: neutral desire condition vs. conflict desire condition) (1) by varying whether the lid of the target container in the present room is locked or unlocked and (2) by varying the rationale of the item choice between conditions and the two experiments: Children either choose one item (a) for re-visiting the future area later only or the choose one item (b) for staying in the present room now and for re-visiting the future area later. In Experiment 1 the current desire is different from, but compatible with the upcoming need whereas in Experiment 2 children's current desire is in conflict with fulfilling the upcoming need. 
Thus we will manipulate the desire condition. The two levels of this variable are termed neutral vs. compatible in Experiment 1 and neutral vs. conflict in Experiment 2.

(1) Episodic Foresight: 
A score ranging from 0 to 5 indicating the ability of Episodic Foresight measured by a task simulation which ascertain the skill to mentally simulate an future event and the competency to use this imagination to guide a current behavior. 
We will measure this step by step with a 'Memory and Knowledge Check':
After the participants chose one of the items in the episodic foresight task they are asked to explain their choice (explanation question; correctly referring gets 2 points, whereas failure to do so results in 0 points). Afterwards two questions test for the children's memory of the problem (memory question-what; correctly referring gets 1 point , whereas failure to do so results in 0 points and memory question-where; correctly referring gets 1point, whereas failure to do so results in 0 points). Finally we will test the usage of the chosen item by observing whether the child will use the item properly (item-use; correctly using the item gets 1 point, whereas failure to do so results in 0 points).  

(2) 'Cool' Executive Functions:
a) Corsi Block Task to assess visual working memory updating. The dependent measure is the number of blocks that the child can correctly reproduce (Bull, Espy, & Wiebe, 2008; Carlson, 2005; Pickering, Gathercole, & Peaker, 1998). 
b) Animal Go/No-Go Task serves as a measure of inhibitory control. The Accuracy of no-go trials is the dependent measure (Willoughby, Wirth, Blair & Family Life Project Investigators, 2012). 
c) Dimensional Change Card Sorting task (DCCS) will measure shifting abilities. A higher number of correctly sorted cards serves as a dependent measure (Zelazo, 2006). 

(3) 'Hot' Executive Functions:
a) Iowa Gambling game ascertains affective decision making. More frequent choices from the more advantageous deck indicate higher 'hot' executive functions (Kerr & Zelazo, 2004). 
b) Forbidden Toy task measures the modulation of affective bottom-up processes. Children with longer waiting times without approaching the toy are thought to have higher 'hot' executive functions (adapted from Lewis et al., 1989).

We will also record age, sex, and conduct an assessment of verbal ability by testing the passive vocabulary of the participants (Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence - III, Wechsler, 2009). These data are collected for the purpose of comparing the sample profiles for each age group.

For each experiment (Experiment 1 and Experiment 2), we plan two logistic regession-based path analyses using the PROCESS tool for SPSS. 

First Analysis: 
Tests whether executive functions (working memory updating, simple and complex inhibition, shifting and hot executive functions, entered as parallel mediators) mediate the relation between age (independent variable) and the probabilitiy to correctly solve the episodic foresight task (dependent variable) when controlling for children's verbal abilities and their memory performance in the episodic foresight task (Hypothesis 1). Furthermore, we test whether a possible mediation by 'hot' executive functions is moderated by children's motivation for a future event and their current desire (Hypothesis 2). 

Second Analysis: 
Tests whether a possible effect of age (independent variables) on the probability to correctly solve the episodic foresight task (dependent variable) depends on the children's motivation for a future event (research question 3) and children's current desire (research question 4), which are entered as two moderators. 
Children's verbal abilities and their memory performance in the episodic foresight task will serve as control variable. 

Using the PROCESS tool for SPSS analyses will provide bias-corrected and accelerated bootstrap confidence intervals for inference about (conditional) indirect effects and indicators of effect size in addition to traditional parameters for regression analyses, such as beta weights (Hayes, 2013).
