children will be required to select one of three presented keys to take back to the future area. Only one key, however, will be suitable to solve the problem. A future-oriented action
will be defined as choosing the right object for the right reason and / or right application. 
In order to manipulate children's motivation to solve the future problem, the different containers include toys of varying topics and varying quantity. We will also manipulate the current desire of the participants by varying the locking of these containers and by varying the rationale of the item choice between conditions and two experiments. In Experiment 1 the current desire is different from, but compatible with the upcoming need whereas in Experiment 2 children's current desire is in conflict with fulfilling the upcoming need. In both experiments, we will assess 'hot' and 'cool' executive functions following the episodic foresight task. 
To sum up, this project examines in two experiments whether differences in episodic foresight between three to five year old children are driven by ('hot' and 'cool') executive functions and also whether the time of emergence of episodic foresight development depends on the motivational significance of the context.
registration_responses.q4:
Research Question 1: Do age-related differences in 'cool' and 'hot' executive function explain why younger preschool children have lower skills in episodic foresight compared to older preschool children?

H1: Age-related differences in 'hot' and 'cool' executive functions explain age-related differences in episodic foresight. 

Research Question 2: Do children's motivation for a future episode and children's current desires affect the relative role of 'hot' executive functions for age-related differences in episodic foresight?

H2: Age-related differences in 'hot' executive functions should more strongly predict age-related differences in episodic foresight, if children head to or are in a motivational significant state, compared to conditions in which children head to or are in a neutral motivational state. 

Research Question 3: How does children's motivation for a future episode influence whether episodic foresight emerges early versus late during preschool years?

H3a: The hot/cool framework predicts a protracted emergence for episodic foresight for events of high personal importance compared to events of less importance. 
H3b: In contrast, the dual competition model suggests a more accelerated emergence under these conditions. 
We will contrast both predictions. 

Research Question 4: How do different types of current motivational states influence whether episodic foresight emerges early versus late during preschool years?

H4a: The hot/cool framework and the dual competition model uniformly predict protracted emergence of episodic foresight, if children hold a current desire while thinking about the future. 
H4b: In contrast, developmental accounts on desire reasoning also propose a decelerated emergence of episodic foresight, but only if current and future motivational perspective are dependent and mutually exclusive, rather than merely different. 
We will contrast both predictions.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined conditions.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
Our target sample size is 544, therefore we will recruit 272 participants for each experiment (Experiment 1 and Experiment 2). 

Thereby in both experiments we will have 96 participants per age-group (3 year-old, 4 year-old and 5 year-old) and 24 participants for each of the 4 conditions. 

We will attempt to recruit up to 640 participants, assuming that not all will complete the total task or numerous data points will likely need to be excluded.
registration_responses.q14:
A simulation study by Preacher and colleagues (2007)  showed that a sample size of N=200 would allow to detect small moderated mediation effect, i.e. a beta of .14 with a power of 65% and medium-sized effects of beta = .39 with a power of 100%. 
In this project we will use dichotomous dependent variables, hence the required sample size will exceed the suggestions of Preacher and colleagues (2007). Analyses with dichotomous variables require about 36% larger samples to achieve the same statistical power that would be found for continuous variables (MacCallum et al., 2002). 
Therefore our target sample size is N = 272 children for each of the two experiments. Assuming that not all will complete the total task or numerous data points will likely need to be excluded, we expect to recruit N = 320 children for each experiment.
registration_responses.q8.question:
The project comprises two experiments with two independent samples. The setting is identical for both experiments, except for the desire condtion (see below). 

We will use a between-subject design wherein the participants will be randomly assigned
to the motivational condition (high and low motivation) as well as to the desire condition (experiment 1: neutral and compatible; experiment 2: neutral and conflict). 

Age group will be a between-subjects factor with three levels: 3 year-old (3;0-3;11) , 4 year-old (4;0-4;11), 5 year-old (5;0-5;11).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited via an already established databank of families who are interested in participating in developmental studies in our lab. 

Parents will  receive 5€ for their time and children will receive small presents worth 5€ for participating. 

Participants will be between 3 and 5 years, born full-term and do not have a history of major medical problems or developmental disorders according to parent report.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We will recruit at three levels of the age variable: 3 year-old (3;0-3;11) , 4 year-old (4;0-4;11), 5 year-old (5;0-5;11). 

In order to manipulate children's motivation to solve the future problem, the container includes toys of varying topics and varying quantity. Thus, we will manipulate the motivational condition. The two levels of this variable are termed high vs. low.

In addition we manipulate children's current desire (Experiment 1: neutral desire condition vs. compatible desire condition; Experiment 2: neutral desire condition vs. conflict desire condition) (1) by varying whether the lid of the target container in the present room is locked or unlocked and (2) by varying the rationale of the item choice between conditions and the two experiments: Children either choose one item (a) for re-visiting the future area later only or the choose one item (b) for staying in the present room now and for re-visiting the future area later. In Experiment 1 the current desire is different from, but compatible with the upcoming need whereas in Experiment 2 children's current desire is in conflict with fulfilling the upcoming need. 
Thus we will manipulate the desire condition. The two levels of this variable are termed neutral vs. compatible in Experiment 1 and neutral vs. conflict in Experiment 2.
registration_responses.q17.question:
(1) Episodic Foresight: 
A score ranging from 0 to 5 indicating the ability of Episodic Foresight measured by a task simulation which ascertain the skill to mentally simulate an future event and the competency to use this imagination to guide a current behavior. 
We will measure this step by step with a 'Memory and Knowledge Check':
After the participants chose one of the items in the episodic foresight task they are asked to explain their choice (explanation question; correctly referring gets 2 points, whereas failure to do so results in 0 points). Afterwards two questions test for the children's memory of the problem (memory question-what; correctly referring gets 1 point , whereas failure to do so results in 0 points and memory question-where; correctly referring gets 1point, whereas failure to do so results in 0 points). Finally we will test the usage of the chosen item by observing whether the child will use the item properly (item-use; correctly using the item gets 1 point, whereas failure to do so results in 0 points).  

(2) 'Cool' Executive Functions:
a) Corsi Block Task to assess visual working memory updating. The dependent measure is the number of blocks that the child can correctly reproduce (Bull, Espy, & Wiebe, 2008; Carlson, 2005; Pickering, Gathercole, & Peaker, 1998). 
b) Animal Go/No-Go Task serves as a measure of inhibitory control. The Accuracy of no-go trials is the dependent measure (Willoughby, Wirth, Blair & Family Life Project Investigators, 2012). 
c) Dimensional Change Card Sorting task (DCCS) will measure shifting abilities. A higher number of correctly sorted cards serves as a dependent measure (Zelazo, 2006). 

(3) 'Hot' Executive Functions:
a) Iowa Gambling game ascertains affective decision making. More frequent choices from the more advantageous deck indicate higher 'hot' executive functions (Kerr & Zelazo, 2004). 
b) Forbidden Toy task measures the modulation of affective bottom-up processes. Children with longer waiting times without approaching the toy are thought to have higher 'hot' executive functions (adapted from Lewis et al., 1989).

We will also record age, sex, and conduct an assessment of verbal ability by testing the passive vocabulary of the participants (Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence - III, Wechsler, 2009). These data are collected for the purpose of comparing the sample profiles for each age group.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For each experiment (Experiment 1 and Experiment 2), we plan two logistic regession-based path analyses using the PROCESS tool for SPSS. 

First Analysis: 
Tests whether executive functions (working memory updating, simple and complex inhibition, shifting and hot executive functions, entered as parallel mediators) mediate the relation between age (independent variable) and the probabilitiy to correctly solve the episodic foresight task (dependent variable) when controlling for children's verbal abilities and their memory performance in the episodic foresight task (Hypothesis 1). Furthermore, we test whether a possible mediation by 'hot' executive functions is moderated by children's motivation for a future event and their current desire (Hypothesis 2). 

Second Analysis: 
Tests whether a possible effect of age (independent variables) on the probability to correctly solve the episodic foresight task (dependent variable) depends on the children's motivation for a future event (research question 3) and children's current desire (research question 4), which are entered as two moderators. 
Children's verbal abilities and their memory performance in the episodic foresight task will serve as control variable. 

Using the PROCESS tool for SPSS analyses will provide bias-corrected and accelerated bootstrap confidence intervals for inference about (conditional) indirect effects and indicators of effect size in addition to traditional parameters for regression analyses, such as beta weights (Hayes, 2013).

attributes.title: Development and Validation of a Virtual Reality Mood Induction

q1.value: Development and Validation of a Virtual Reality Mood Induction

q2.value: Kathleen M. Walsh, Norman Farb, Zindel V. Segal

q3.value: A variety of mood induction procedures have been developed and consistently employed in emotion research. Moreover, mood induction procedures are useful for investigating emotion regulation strategies and predictors of psychopathology. Recent research has shown that immersive virtual reality (VR) technology may be an effective mood induction platform in eliciting feelings of relaxation and anxiety that are closely related to real-world contexts. Moreover, the feelings of presence (sense of being in the virtual environment) experienced in VR may contribute to the degree that emotions are elicited, suggesting that this platform may increase efficiency and effectiveness in inducing mood. Therefore, the broad goal of this study is to develop and validate a novel VR mood induction paradigm that can effectively elicit negative and positive emotions through realistic interpersonal scenarios.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1a: Videos depicting social scenarios developed for this study will significantly illicit their target valence (negative, positive) relative to their neutral counterparts.
•	Hypothesis 1a.i: Main effect of negative videos: The negative videos will have a lower mean valence rating than the neutral videos.
•	Hypothesis 1a.ii: Main effect of positive videos: The positive videos will have a higher mean valence rating than the neutral videos.
Hypothesis 1b: The negative and positive videos will produce greater levels of arousal relative to the neutral videos.
•	Hypothesis 1b.i: Main effect of strong videos: The negative and positive videos combined will have a higher mean arousal rating relative to their neutral videos.

Hypothesis 2: The positive and negative virtual reality videos will be more effective in eliciting emotions, in terms of valence and arousal, relative to the same social scenarios as non-immersive flat videos.
•	Hypothesis 2a: Interactions between video group and video valence when predicting subjective valence. 
o	Hypothesis 2a.i: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Negative vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater valence differences than Flat videos.
o	Hypothesis 2a.ii: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Positive vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater valence differences than Flat videos.
•	Hypothesis 2b: Interaction between video group and video valence when predicting subjective arousal.
o	Hypothesis 2b.i: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Positive & Negative vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will have a higher mean arousal rating relative to the Flat videos. 

Hypothesis 3: The social scenarios viewed in virtual reality (VR) will produce greater feelings of presence compared to viewing the same social scenarios on a non-immersive platform (Flat videos).
•	Hypothesis 3.i: Main effect of video group: the VR video group will have a higher mean presence rating relative to the Flat video group.
•	Hypothesis 3.ii: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Negative vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater presence rating differences than Flat videos
•	Hypothesis 3.iii: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Positive vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater presence rating differences than Flat videos

Hypothesis 4: Differences in valence and arousal between virtual reality videos and non-immersive flat videos will be mediated by ratings of presence.
•	Hypothesis 4a: Relationship between video group (VR vs. Flat) and evoked valence ratings will be mediated by subjective presence ratings.
•	Hypothesis 4b: Relationship between video group (VR vs. Flat) and subjective arousal ratings will be mediated by subjective presence ratings.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Although participants in the study know that they will either watch videos in virtual reality or on the computer, they are blind to which is the control condition and which is the experimental condition.

question.value: We have a mixed study design with (a) a within-subjects factor (Video Valence) that has 3 levels (negative, positive, neutral) and (b) a between-subjects factor (Video Group) that has 2 levels (VR group, Flat film group). Participants will be randomized on the between-subjects factor. The videos that participants view will be presented in randomized blocks of 6 according to the video’s valence. (i.e., 5 negative videos then 5 neutral videos). The videos will be randomized between and within blocks. Additionally, a within-subjects factor (Trial Number) that has a 6 levels (6 trials of a cognitive task) will be used to assess participants effort over the duration of the study.

q9.value:
Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of two equally sized groups through a permuted block randomization procedure. The blocks and resulting random sequence will be generated through a function called randomizeR (Uschner et al., 2018) in the statistical platform R 3.4.3 (R Core Team, 2017).

References
*R Core Team. (2017). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria. Retrieved from https://www.R-project.org/
*Uschner, D., Schindler, D., Hilgers, RD., & Heussen, N. (2018). randomizeR: An R package for the assessment and implementation of randomization in clinical trials. Journal of Statistical Software, 85(8).

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
A student sample will be recruited through the University of Toronto Mississauga participant pool – PsychED. Prospective participants will be screened online for inclusion and exclusion criteria and scheduled for a 2-hour in-person session if criteria are met. All participants will be tested in the Regulatory and Affective Dynamics Laboratory at University Toronto Mississauga. Participants will receive course credit for their participation with 2 credit hours equivalent to 4/3 final marks in Psy100. Alternatively, participants signing up for pay will be paid minimum wage ($11.05) for 2 hours of participation, equal to $22.10. Primary inclusion criteria will include: (a) 18 years of age or older, and (b) self-described as fluent in both spoken and written English. Exclusion criteria will include: (a) current or past diagnosis of a psychotic disorder, depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, anxiety disorder, substance dependence disorder, acute or unstable medical disorder, or intellectual disability; (b) current antidepressant or anxiolytic treatment regiment, (c) currently participating in psychosocial treatment, and (d) a history of motion sickness. 

At the onset of the lab session participants will provide informed consent and complete a demographic survey. Participants will then be randomized into two groups: a group that will watch the virtual reality (VR) scenarios (VR group) and a group that will watch non-immersive film scenarios (Flat film group). Before watching the social scenarios, participants will watch a neutral video for 2-minutes in their assigned group (VR or Flat) and then be asked questions about symptoms of cybersickness. If participants report slight or moderate symptoms of cybersickness (Ames et al., 2005), they will be asked if they feel well enough to continue on with the study. If they decide not to continue, they will receive their compensation and be completed with the study. If participants report severe symptoms of cybersickness (Ames et al., 2005), they will receive their compensation and be completed with the study. Participants who continue with the study will watch 30 social scenarios (~1 minute/scenario with thirty 30 sec breaks x 30 = ~45 minutes). The VR group will watch these scenarios using an Oculus Rift VR headset and the Flat film group will watch these scenarios on a computer monitor. Participants will watch each of these scenarios in randomized blocks of negative, positive, and neutral valenced videos, with 5 consecutive videos of the same type (i.e., 5 neutral, 5 positive, or 5 negative) in a row. No video will be repeated so that participants view each of the 30 videos exactly once. Participants will provide ratings of valence, arousal, and presence after each video. To reduce carry over effects from one block of social scenario videos to another, participants will complete a short (2-minute) cognitive distractor task to ‘clear their mind’ and distract them from the current mood they may be experiencing (see James et al., 2016; Van Dillen et al., 2007). The cognitive distractor task will also be used to assess participants effort during the study based on expected attrition of task performance across the 6 blocks. Both groups will complete the cognitive distractor task on a computer screen- the VR group will simply slide up the VR headset to complete the task between video blocks.

Ideal but approximate timeline: 
Data collection will run from February 2020 to June 2020
Data analysis will be conducted starting June 2020 and onward.

References
*Ames, S. L., Wolffsohn, J. S., & McBrien, N. A. (2005). The development of a symptom questionnaire for assessing virtual reality viewing using a head-mounted display. Optometry and Vision Science: Official Publication of the American Academy of Optometry, 82(3), 168–176.
*James, E. L., Lau-Zhu, A., Clark, I. A., Visser, R. M., Hagenaars, M. A., & Holmes, E. A. (2016). The trauma film paradigm as an experimental psychopathology model of psychological trauma: Intrusive memories and beyond. Clinical Psychology Review, 47, 106–142. doi:10.1016/j.cpr.2016.04.010
*Van Dillen, L. F., & Koole, S. L. (2007). Clearing the mind: a working memory model of distraction from negative mood. Emotion (Washington, D.C.), 7(4), 715–723. doi: 10.1037/1528-3542.7.4.715

q13.value: The target sample size is 120, with 60 participants in each group (VR group and Flat film group). We will attempt to recruit 130 participants to account for any technical problems that may occur during data collection.

q14.value:
A power analysis was conducted using the simr function in R 3.4.3. for the most complex multilevel model that will be conducted in the study. For example, a data set was first simulated with one continuous outcome variable (e.g., subjective valence), a categorical predictor with 2 levels (e.g., video group), a categorical predictor with 3 levels (e.g., video valence), and a random intercept for the 2nd level nesting variable in the multilevel model (e.g., participant). Parameters were estimated for each of the three main effects: (1) video group (VR vs. Flat) estimated slope beta value = 0.64, (2) negative valence (negative vs. neutral) estimated slope beta value = 0.64, and (3) positive valence (positive vs. neutral) estimated slope beta value = 0.64. Parameters were also estimated for the two interactions: (1) video group and negative valence interaction estimated slope beta value = 0.4, and (2) video group and positive valence interaction estimated slope beta value = 0.4. Lastly, parameters were estimated for residual variance = 0.50 and the random intercept variance = 0.50. These parameters were estimated to assume a medium effect size for each of the main effects (d = 0.50) and a small effect size for each of the interactions (d = 0.22). A simulation based method, with 10,000 simulations, was conducted for the power calculation. This simulation suggested that 120 participants would be needed for 90% power. 

A power analysis was also conducted for the proposed multilevel mediation models in the study using the Monte Carlo Power Analysis for Indirect Effects created by the Methodology and Analysis Research Lab (Shoemann et al., 2017). A medium sized correlation (r = 0.30) between the predictor (e.g., video group) and mediator (e.g., subjective presence), small correlation (r = 0.15) between the predictor and outcome (e.g., evoked valence), small correlation (r = 0.15) between the mediator and outcome, and a standard deviation of 1 was assumed. This analysis, with 10,000 simulations, suggested that we would need 800 data points to achieve 90% power. Given that we have 30 trials (videos) per participant we would only need about 25 participants to achieve sufficient power. As such, we are planning to power for the trial level effect of average presence on evoked valence and not the participant level effect. Therefore, the proposed 120 participants to power for the multilevel models will be sufficient for the multilevel mediation. As such, to account for possible technical problems during data collection, a sample of 130 participants was determined as sufficient to power the study.

References
* Schoemann, A. M., Boulton, A. J., & Short, S. D. (2017). Determining power and sample size for simple and complex mediation models. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 8, 379-386

question.value:
Video Group: This is a categorical between subjects variable with 2 levels. The first level is the VR group where participants will watch the videos in the study using a virtual reality headset. The second level is the Flat film group where participants will watch the videos in the study on a computer monitor. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of these two groups.

Video Valence: This is a categorical within subjects variable with 3 levels. Within each video scenario (e.g., double date, meeting with a doctor) there will be three video versions each developed to elicit a specific valence. Therefore, the levels of this variable each represent 1 of 3 valence types: negative valence, positive valence, and neutral valence. 

Video Valence Combined: This is a categorical within subjects variable with 2 levels. The first level will represent neutral valence and the second level will represent strong valence (negative valence and positive valence).

Cognitive Trial: This is a categorical within subjects variable with 6 levels. Each level represents the point in time during the study that participants complete a cognitive task (the symbol digit modalities test), which will be completed 6 times. 

Participant: This variable represents each individual participant in the study.

Subjective Valence: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree of valence that participants experience after watching a video. This variable will be measured with the Affective Sliding scale (Betella & Verschure, 2016), which is a digital scale, ranging from 0 to 100,  designed for the self-assessment of emotion.

Subjective Arousal: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree of arousal that participants experience after watching a video. This variable will be measured with the Affective Sliding scale (Betella & Verschure, 2016), which  is a digital scale, ranging from 0 to 100, designed for the self-assessment of emotion.

Subjective Presence: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree of presence, defined as the sense of actually “being” in the virtual environment, that participants experience while watching a video. This variable will be measured with the Slater-Usoh-Steed (SUS) questionnaire (Slater, Usoh, & Steed, 1994, 1995). The SUS is a 3-item self-report questionnaire where respondents provide ratings on a 7-point Likert scale.

Evoked Valence: This is a continuous variable reflecting the deviation of the negative and positive valence scores from the neutral valence score for each participant. This variable will be used to test the mediation model. Specific calculation can be found in the indices.

SDMT Score: This is a continuous variable reflecting participants performance on the Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT; Smith, 1982), which will be used to reduce carry over effects of affect from one block of social scenario videos to another and to assess effort. In this task, participants will be given an answer key consisting of symbol-number pairs. Participants then have a time limit to fill in rows of blank squares, each labeled with a symbol, with the correct number according to the key. Their performance is calculated by the number of correct responses made within a 2-minute time period.

Expectancy Violation Score: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree that participants expectation of feeling immersed in the videos was violated. This variable will be measured by a 2-item self-report questionnaire where respondents provide ratings on a 7-point Likert scale. Participants will respond to question 1 (Q1) at the start of the study and to question 2 (Q2) at the end of the study. (Q1) Expectancy: I expect that watching (VR/computer) videos will be highly immersive and engaging (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree) and (Q2) Actual Experience: Watching (VR/computer) videos was highly immersive and engaging (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree). Specific calculation can be found in the indices.

References
*Betella, A., & Verschure, P. F. M. J. (2016). The affective slider: A digital self-assessment scale for the measurement of human emotions. PLoS ONE, 11(2). Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/1788556258/7DF65F14E9384E69PQ/1
*Slater, M., Usoh, M., & Steed, A. (1994). Depth of Presence in Virtual Environments. Retrieved August 15, 2018, from /paper/Depth-of-Presence-in-Virtual-Environments-Slater-Usoh/857f768894583b738533585897594824c55a3bec 
*Slater, M., Usoh, M., & Steed, A. (1995). Taking Steps: The Influence of a Walking Technique on Presence in Virtual Reality. ACM Trans. Comput.-Hum. Interact., 2(3), 201–219. https://doi.org/10.1145/210079.210084
*Smith, A. (1982). Symbol digit modalities test (SDMT) Manual. Los Angeles: Western Psychological Services.

Video Group: as described in manipulated variables.

Video Valence: as described in manipulated variables.

Video Valence Combined: as described in manipulated variables.

Cognitive Trial: as described in manipulated variables.

Subjective Valence: as described in measured variables.

Subjective Arousal: as described in measured variables.

Subjective Presence: as described in measured variables.

Evoked Valence:  This variable will be calculated by taking the mean neutral subjective valence score for each participant and subtracting it from each of their neutral, negative, and positive subjective valence scores. The absolute value (which will be blind to the direction of the valence) will be the Evoked Valence score. 

SDMT score: as described in measured variables.

Expectancy Violation Score: This variable will be calculated by subtracting the score from question 1 (expectancy question) from the score on question 2 (actual experience). This difference score will then represent the degree that participants expectations were violated.

Hypothesis 1a: Predicting (1a.i) main effect of positive valence vs. neutral valence and (1a.ii) main effect of negative valence vs. neutral valence
Test: 2-level MLM with a fixed slope and random intercept.
-Model 1a.1: Subjective Valence ~ Video Valence + (1|Participant) 
-DV = Subjective Valence 
-IV = Video Valence 
-Random Intercept = Participant

Hypothesis 1b: Predicting a (1b.i) main effect of strong valence vs. neutral valence
Test: 2-level MLM with a fixed slope and random intercept.
Model 1b.1: Subjective Arousal ~ Video Valence Combined + (1|Participant)
-DV = Subjective Arousal
-IV = Video Valence Combined
-Random Intercept = Participant

Hypothesis 2a: Predicting (2a.i) an interaction between VR group vs. Flat film group and positive valence vs. neutral valence and (2a.ii) an interaction between VR group vs. Flat film group and negative valence vs. neutral valence.
Test: 2-level MLM with a random slope, to account for the cross-level interaction, and a random intercept.
Model 2a: Subjective Valence ~ Video Valence * Video Group + (Video Valence|Participant) 
-IV = Subjective Valence
-DVs = Video Valence, Video Group
-Random Slope = Video Valence
-Random Intercept = Participant
Simple Effects Analysis: To investigate and interpret significant interactions simple effects with the estimated means will be conducted using the FDR adjustment to correct for multiple comparisons. 

Hypothesis 2b: Predicting an (2b.i) interaction between VR group vs. Flat film group and strong valence vs. neutral valence. 
Test: 2-level MLM with a random slope, to account for the cross-level interaction, and a random intercept.
Model 2b: Subjective Arousal ~ Video Valence Combined * Video Group + (Video Valence Combined|Participant) 
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DVs = Video Valence Combined, Video Group
-Random Slope = Video Valence Combined
-Random Intercept = Participant
Simple Effects Analysis: To investigate and interpret significant interactions simple effects with the estimated means will be conducted using the FDR adjustment to correct for multiple comparisons.

Hypothesis 3: Predicting (3.i) a main effect of VR group vs. Film group, (3.ii) an interaction between VR group vs. Flat film group and positive valence vs. neutral valence, and (3.iii) an interaction between VR group vs. Flat film group and negative valence vs. neutral valence.
Test: 2-level MLM with a random slope, to account for the cross-level interaction, and a random intercept.
Model 3: Subjective Presence ~ Video Valence * Video Group + (Video Valence|Participant) 
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DVs = Video Valence, Video Group
-Random Slope = Video Valence 
-Random Intercept = Participant
Simple Effects Analysis: To investigate and interpret significant interactions simple effects with the estimated means will be conducted using the FDR adjustment to correct for multiple comparisons.

Hypothesis 4a: Subjective presence will mediate the relationship between Video Group and Evoked Valence.
Test: 2-1-1 MLM mediation model using causal steps in conjunction with the Sobel’s test with a group (Participant) mean centered mediator and mediator group (Participant) average as a covariate to account for possible deviations of the group (Participant) at level-2 or the individual from their group (Participant) at level-1.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 (a-path): Subjective Presence ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2 (c-path): Evoked Valence ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
-IV = Evoked Valence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3 (b-path): Evoked Valence ~ Video Group + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence + Average Subjective Presence per Participant + (1|Participant)
-IV = Evoked Valence
-DVs = Video Group, Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Covariate = Average Subjective Presence per Participant
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4 (a-path slope): Subjective Presence ~ Video Group + (0 + Video Group|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Slope = Video Group with no variation in intercept
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 5 (b-path slope): Evoked Valence ~ Video Group + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence + Average Subjective Presence per Participant + (1 + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence |Participant)
-IV = Subjective Valence
-DVs = Video Group, Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Covariate = Average Subjective Presence per Participant
-Random Slope = Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sobel’s Test: To investigate whether the indirect effect is consistent across level 2 groups a correlation will be conducted with the a-path slope estimates and b-path slope estimates. If the relationship between the a-path slopes and b-path slopes is significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model with the random slopes. If this relationship is not significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model without random slopes. 

Hypothesis 4b: Subjective presence will mediate the relationship between Video Group and Subjective Arousal.
Test: 2-1-1 MLM mediation model using causal steps in conjunction with the Sobel’s test with a group (Participant) mean centered mediator and mediator group (Participant) average as a covariate to account for possible deviations of the group (Participant) at level-2 or the individual from their group (Participant) at level-1.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 (a-path): Subjective Presence ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2 (c-path): Subjective Arousal ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DV = Video Group
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3 (b-path): Subjective Arousal ~ Video Group + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence + Average Subjective Presence per Participant + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DVs = Video Group, Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Covariate = Average Subjective Presence per Participant
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4 (a-path slope): Subjective Presence ~ Video Group + (0 + Video Group|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Slope = Video Group with no variation in intercept
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 5 (b-path slope): Subjective Arousal ~ Video Group + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence + Average Subjective Presence per Participant + (1 + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence |Participant)
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DVs = Video Group, Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Covariate = Average Subjective Presence per Participant
-Random Slope = Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sobel’s Test: To investigate whether the indirect effect is consistent across level 2 groups a correlation will be conducted with the a-path slope estimates and b-path slope estimates. If the relationship between the a-path slopes and b-path slopes is significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model with the random slopes. If this relationship is not significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model without random slopes. 

Participant Characteristics: Each of the participant characteristics will be compared between the Film and VR groups using chi-square tests for the categorical characteristics (i.e., marital status) and t-tests for the continuous characteristics (i.e., age). Any characteristics that are significantly different between the VR and Film groups will be entered as a covariate in the main analyses to control for these differences.

Effort Over Time: Assessing for a main effect of trial number.  
Test: 2-level MLM with a fixed slope and random intercept.
Effort Model: SDMT Score ~ Cognitive Trials + (1|Participant)
DV: SDMT Score
IV: Cognitive Trials
Random Intercept: Participant
If there is a significant decrease in performance over trials, suggested by a main effect of trial number, this variable will be entered as a covariate in the main analyses to control for effort.

Expectancy Violation: Assessing for a main effect of Video Group.
Test: 2-level MLM with a fixed slope and random intercept.
Expectancy Model: Expectancy Violation Score ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
DV: Expectancy Violation Score
IV: Video Group
Random Intercept: Participant
If there is a significant difference between Video Group (VR vs. Flat film), suggested by a main effect of Video Group, this variable will be entered as a covariate in the main analyses to control for this difference. 

Assumptions: Assumptions for each of the MLMs will be tested. Linearity will be investigated through visual inspection of a plot of the model residuals vs. the predictor. Homogeneity of variance will be investigated through the Levene’s test and through visual inspection of the residual vs. fitted value plots. Normally distributed residuals will be investigated through a visual inspection of Q-Q plots and histogram of the residuals. Lastly, influential cases/outliers will be identified by calculating cook’s distance for each model. If assumptions are violated, transformations will be conducted only if violations are extreme and results will be reported with the caveat that assumptions are violated.

To test for sufficient clustering, each of the baseline multilevel models (MLM) for the hypotheses will be conducted and the design effect (DEFF) calculated.
H1a, H2a, and H4 Baseline Model = Subjective Valence ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Subjective Valence 
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
H1b, H2b, and H4 Baseline Model = Subjective Arousal ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Subjective Arousal
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
H3 and H4 Baseline Model = Subjective Presence ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Subjective Presence
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Assessment of effort baseline model = SDMT Score ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = SDMT Score
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Expectancy violation baseline model = Expectancy Violation Score ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Expectancy Violation Score
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant

registration_responses.q1: Development and Validation of a Virtual Reality Mood Induction
registration_responses.q2: Kathleen M. Walsh, Norman Farb, Zindel V. Segal
registration_responses.q3: A variety of mood induction procedures have been developed and consistently employed in emotion research. Moreover, mood induction procedures are useful for investigating emotion regulation strategies and predictors of psychopathology. Recent research has shown that immersive virtual reality (VR) technology may be an effective mood induction platform in eliciting feelings of relaxation and anxiety that are closely related to real-world contexts. Moreover, the feelings of presence (sense of being in the virtual environment) experienced in VR may contribute to the degree that emotions are elicited, suggesting that this platform may increase efficiency and effectiveness in inducing mood. Therefore, the broad goal of this study is to develop and validate a novel VR mood induction paradigm that can effectively elicit negative and positive emotions through realistic interpersonal scenarios.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1a: Videos depicting social scenarios developed for this study will significantly illicit their target valence (negative, positive) relative to their neutral counterparts.
•	Hypothesis 1a.i: Main effect of negative videos: The negative videos will have a lower mean valence rating than the neutral videos.
•	Hypothesis 1a.ii: Main effect of positive videos: The positive videos will have a higher mean valence rating than the neutral videos.
Hypothesis 1b: The negative and positive videos will produce greater levels of arousal relative to the neutral videos.
•	Hypothesis 1b.i: Main effect of strong videos: The negative and positive videos combined will have a higher mean arousal rating relative to their neutral videos.

Hypothesis 2: The positive and negative virtual reality videos will be more effective in eliciting emotions, in terms of valence and arousal, relative to the same social scenarios as non-immersive flat videos.
•	Hypothesis 2a: Interactions between video group and video valence when predicting subjective valence. 
o	Hypothesis 2a.i: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Negative vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater valence differences than Flat videos.
o	Hypothesis 2a.ii: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Positive vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater valence differences than Flat videos.
•	Hypothesis 2b: Interaction between video group and video valence when predicting subjective arousal.
o	Hypothesis 2b.i: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Positive & Negative vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will have a higher mean arousal rating relative to the Flat videos. 

Hypothesis 3: The social scenarios viewed in virtual reality (VR) will produce greater feelings of presence compared to viewing the same social scenarios on a non-immersive platform (Flat videos).
•	Hypothesis 3.i: Main effect of video group: the VR video group will have a higher mean presence rating relative to the Flat video group.
•	Hypothesis 3.ii: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Negative vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater presence rating differences than Flat videos
•	Hypothesis 3.iii: Group (VR vs. Flat) and Video Valence (Positive vs. Neutral) will interact such that VR videos will yield greater presence rating differences than Flat videos

Hypothesis 4: Differences in valence and arousal between virtual reality videos and non-immersive flat videos will be mediated by ratings of presence.
•	Hypothesis 4a: Relationship between video group (VR vs. Flat) and evoked valence ratings will be mediated by subjective presence ratings.
•	Hypothesis 4b: Relationship between video group (VR vs. Flat) and subjective arousal ratings will be mediated by subjective presence ratings.

Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of two equally sized groups through a permuted block randomization procedure. The blocks and resulting random sequence will be generated through a function called randomizeR (Uschner et al., 2018) in the statistical platform R 3.4.3 (R Core Team, 2017).

References
*R Core Team. (2017). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria. Retrieved from https://www.R-project.org/
*Uschner, D., Schindler, D., Hilgers, RD., & Heussen, N. (2018). randomizeR: An R package for the assessment and implementation of randomization in clinical trials. Journal of Statistical Software, 85(8).

registration_responses.q13: The target sample size is 120, with 60 participants in each group (VR group and Flat film group). We will attempt to recruit 130 participants to account for any technical problems that may occur during data collection.
registration_responses.q14:
A power analysis was conducted using the simr function in R 3.4.3. for the most complex multilevel model that will be conducted in the study. For example, a data set was first simulated with one continuous outcome variable (e.g., subjective valence), a categorical predictor with 2 levels (e.g., video group), a categorical predictor with 3 levels (e.g., video valence), and a random intercept for the 2nd level nesting variable in the multilevel model (e.g., participant). Parameters were estimated for each of the three main effects: (1) video group (VR vs. Flat) estimated slope beta value = 0.64, (2) negative valence (negative vs. neutral) estimated slope beta value = 0.64, and (3) positive valence (positive vs. neutral) estimated slope beta value = 0.64. Parameters were also estimated for the two interactions: (1) video group and negative valence interaction estimated slope beta value = 0.4, and (2) video group and positive valence interaction estimated slope beta value = 0.4. Lastly, parameters were estimated for residual variance = 0.50 and the random intercept variance = 0.50. These parameters were estimated to assume a medium effect size for each of the main effects (d = 0.50) and a small effect size for each of the interactions (d = 0.22). A simulation based method, with 10,000 simulations, was conducted for the power calculation. This simulation suggested that 120 participants would be needed for 90% power. 

A power analysis was also conducted for the proposed multilevel mediation models in the study using the Monte Carlo Power Analysis for Indirect Effects created by the Methodology and Analysis Research Lab (Shoemann et al., 2017). A medium sized correlation (r = 0.30) between the predictor (e.g., video group) and mediator (e.g., subjective presence), small correlation (r = 0.15) between the predictor and outcome (e.g., evoked valence), small correlation (r = 0.15) between the mediator and outcome, and a standard deviation of 1 was assumed. This analysis, with 10,000 simulations, suggested that we would need 800 data points to achieve 90% power. Given that we have 30 trials (videos) per participant we would only need about 25 participants to achieve sufficient power. As such, we are planning to power for the trial level effect of average presence on evoked valence and not the participant level effect. Therefore, the proposed 120 participants to power for the multilevel models will be sufficient for the multilevel mediation. As such, to account for possible technical problems during data collection, a sample of 130 participants was determined as sufficient to power the study.

References
* Schoemann, A. M., Boulton, A. J., & Short, S. D. (2017). Determining power and sample size for simple and complex mediation models. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 8, 379-386

registration_responses.q8.question: We have a mixed study design with (a) a within-subjects factor (Video Valence) that has 3 levels (negative, positive, neutral) and (b) a between-subjects factor (Video Group) that has 2 levels (VR group, Flat film group). Participants will be randomized on the between-subjects factor. The videos that participants view will be presented in randomized blocks of 6 according to the video’s valence. (i.e., 5 negative videos then 5 neutral videos). The videos will be randomized between and within blocks. Additionally, a within-subjects factor (Trial Number) that has a 6 levels (6 trials of a cognitive task) will be used to assess participants effort over the duration of the study.
registration_responses.q12.question:
A student sample will be recruited through the University of Toronto Mississauga participant pool – PsychED. Prospective participants will be screened online for inclusion and exclusion criteria and scheduled for a 2-hour in-person session if criteria are met. All participants will be tested in the Regulatory and Affective Dynamics Laboratory at University Toronto Mississauga. Participants will receive course credit for their participation with 2 credit hours equivalent to 4/3 final marks in Psy100. Alternatively, participants signing up for pay will be paid minimum wage ($11.05) for 2 hours of participation, equal to $22.10. Primary inclusion criteria will include: (a) 18 years of age or older, and (b) self-described as fluent in both spoken and written English. Exclusion criteria will include: (a) current or past diagnosis of a psychotic disorder, depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, anxiety disorder, substance dependence disorder, acute or unstable medical disorder, or intellectual disability; (b) current antidepressant or anxiolytic treatment regiment, (c) currently participating in psychosocial treatment, and (d) a history of motion sickness. 

At the onset of the lab session participants will provide informed consent and complete a demographic survey. Participants will then be randomized into two groups: a group that will watch the virtual reality (VR) scenarios (VR group) and a group that will watch non-immersive film scenarios (Flat film group). Before watching the social scenarios, participants will watch a neutral video for 2-minutes in their assigned group (VR or Flat) and then be asked questions about symptoms of cybersickness. If participants report slight or moderate symptoms of cybersickness (Ames et al., 2005), they will be asked if they feel well enough to continue on with the study. If they decide not to continue, they will receive their compensation and be completed with the study. If participants report severe symptoms of cybersickness (Ames et al., 2005), they will receive their compensation and be completed with the study. Participants who continue with the study will watch 30 social scenarios (~1 minute/scenario with thirty 30 sec breaks x 30 = ~45 minutes). The VR group will watch these scenarios using an Oculus Rift VR headset and the Flat film group will watch these scenarios on a computer monitor. Participants will watch each of these scenarios in randomized blocks of negative, positive, and neutral valenced videos, with 5 consecutive videos of the same type (i.e., 5 neutral, 5 positive, or 5 negative) in a row. No video will be repeated so that participants view each of the 30 videos exactly once. Participants will provide ratings of valence, arousal, and presence after each video. To reduce carry over effects from one block of social scenario videos to another, participants will complete a short (2-minute) cognitive distractor task to ‘clear their mind’ and distract them from the current mood they may be experiencing (see James et al., 2016; Van Dillen et al., 2007). The cognitive distractor task will also be used to assess participants effort during the study based on expected attrition of task performance across the 6 blocks. Both groups will complete the cognitive distractor task on a computer screen- the VR group will simply slide up the VR headset to complete the task between video blocks.

Ideal but approximate timeline: 
Data collection will run from February 2020 to June 2020
Data analysis will be conducted starting June 2020 and onward.

References
*Ames, S. L., Wolffsohn, J. S., & McBrien, N. A. (2005). The development of a symptom questionnaire for assessing virtual reality viewing using a head-mounted display. Optometry and Vision Science: Official Publication of the American Academy of Optometry, 82(3), 168–176.
*James, E. L., Lau-Zhu, A., Clark, I. A., Visser, R. M., Hagenaars, M. A., & Holmes, E. A. (2016). The trauma film paradigm as an experimental psychopathology model of psychological trauma: Intrusive memories and beyond. Clinical Psychology Review, 47, 106–142. doi:10.1016/j.cpr.2016.04.010
*Van Dillen, L. F., & Koole, S. L. (2007). Clearing the mind: a working memory model of distraction from negative mood. Emotion (Washington, D.C.), 7(4), 715–723. doi: 10.1037/1528-3542.7.4.715
registration_responses.q16.question:
Video Group: This is a categorical between subjects variable with 2 levels. The first level is the VR group where participants will watch the videos in the study using a virtual reality headset. The second level is the Flat film group where participants will watch the videos in the study on a computer monitor. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of these two groups.

Video Valence: This is a categorical within subjects variable with 3 levels. Within each video scenario (e.g., double date, meeting with a doctor) there will be three video versions each developed to elicit a specific valence. Therefore, the levels of this variable each represent 1 of 3 valence types: negative valence, positive valence, and neutral valence. 

Video Valence Combined: This is a categorical within subjects variable with 2 levels. The first level will represent neutral valence and the second level will represent strong valence (negative valence and positive valence).

Cognitive Trial: This is a categorical within subjects variable with 6 levels. Each level represents the point in time during the study that participants complete a cognitive task (the symbol digit modalities test), which will be completed 6 times. 

Participant: This variable represents each individual participant in the study.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Subjective Valence: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree of valence that participants experience after watching a video. This variable will be measured with the Affective Sliding scale (Betella & Verschure, 2016), which is a digital scale, ranging from 0 to 100,  designed for the self-assessment of emotion.

Subjective Arousal: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree of arousal that participants experience after watching a video. This variable will be measured with the Affective Sliding scale (Betella & Verschure, 2016), which  is a digital scale, ranging from 0 to 100, designed for the self-assessment of emotion.

Subjective Presence: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree of presence, defined as the sense of actually “being” in the virtual environment, that participants experience while watching a video. This variable will be measured with the Slater-Usoh-Steed (SUS) questionnaire (Slater, Usoh, & Steed, 1994, 1995). The SUS is a 3-item self-report questionnaire where respondents provide ratings on a 7-point Likert scale.

Evoked Valence: This is a continuous variable reflecting the deviation of the negative and positive valence scores from the neutral valence score for each participant. This variable will be used to test the mediation model. Specific calculation can be found in the indices.

SDMT Score: This is a continuous variable reflecting participants performance on the Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT; Smith, 1982), which will be used to reduce carry over effects of affect from one block of social scenario videos to another and to assess effort. In this task, participants will be given an answer key consisting of symbol-number pairs. Participants then have a time limit to fill in rows of blank squares, each labeled with a symbol, with the correct number according to the key. Their performance is calculated by the number of correct responses made within a 2-minute time period.

Expectancy Violation Score: This is a continuous variable reflecting the degree that participants expectation of feeling immersed in the videos was violated. This variable will be measured by a 2-item self-report questionnaire where respondents provide ratings on a 7-point Likert scale. Participants will respond to question 1 (Q1) at the start of the study and to question 2 (Q2) at the end of the study. (Q1) Expectancy: I expect that watching (VR/computer) videos will be highly immersive and engaging (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree) and (Q2) Actual Experience: Watching (VR/computer) videos was highly immersive and engaging (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree). Specific calculation can be found in the indices.

References
*Betella, A., & Verschure, P. F. M. J. (2016). The affective slider: A digital self-assessment scale for the measurement of human emotions. PLoS ONE, 11(2). Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/1788556258/7DF65F14E9384E69PQ/1
*Slater, M., Usoh, M., & Steed, A. (1994). Depth of Presence in Virtual Environments. Retrieved August 15, 2018, from /paper/Depth-of-Presence-in-Virtual-Environments-Slater-Usoh/857f768894583b738533585897594824c55a3bec 
*Slater, M., Usoh, M., & Steed, A. (1995). Taking Steps: The Influence of a Walking Technique on Presence in Virtual Reality. ACM Trans. Comput.-Hum. Interact., 2(3), 201–219. https://doi.org/10.1145/210079.210084
*Smith, A. (1982). Symbol digit modalities test (SDMT) Manual. Los Angeles: Western Psychological Services.

Evoked Valence:  This variable will be calculated by taking the mean neutral subjective valence score for each participant and subtracting it from each of their neutral, negative, and positive subjective valence scores. The absolute value (which will be blind to the direction of the valence) will be the Evoked Valence score. 

SDMT score: as described in measured variables.

Expectancy Violation Score: This variable will be calculated by subtracting the score from question 1 (expectancy question) from the score on question 2 (actual experience). This difference score will then represent the degree that participants expectations were violated.

-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sobel’s Test: To investigate whether the indirect effect is consistent across level 2 groups a correlation will be conducted with the a-path slope estimates and b-path slope estimates. If the relationship between the a-path slopes and b-path slopes is significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model with the random slopes. If this relationship is not significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model without random slopes. 

Hypothesis 4b: Subjective presence will mediate the relationship between Video Group and Subjective Arousal.
Test: 2-1-1 MLM mediation model using causal steps in conjunction with the Sobel’s test with a group (Participant) mean centered mediator and mediator group (Participant) average as a covariate to account for possible deviations of the group (Participant) at level-2 or the individual from their group (Participant) at level-1.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 (a-path): Subjective Presence ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2 (c-path): Subjective Arousal ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DV = Video Group
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3 (b-path): Subjective Arousal ~ Video Group + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence + Average Subjective Presence per Participant + (1|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DVs = Video Group, Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Covariate = Average Subjective Presence per Participant
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4 (a-path slope): Subjective Presence ~ Video Group + (0 + Video Group|Participant)
-IV = Subjective Presence
-DV = Video Group
-Random Slope = Video Group with no variation in intercept
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 5 (b-path slope): Subjective Arousal ~ Video Group + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence + Average Subjective Presence per Participant + (1 + Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence |Participant)
-IV = Subjective Arousal
-DVs = Video Group, Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Covariate = Average Subjective Presence per Participant
-Random Slope = Participant Mean Centered Subjective Presence
-Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sobel’s Test: To investigate whether the indirect effect is consistent across level 2 groups a correlation will be conducted with the a-path slope estimates and b-path slope estimates. If the relationship between the a-path slopes and b-path slopes is significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model with the random slopes. If this relationship is not significant then the Sobel test will be conducted with the estimates from the mediation model without random slopes. 

Participant Characteristics: Each of the participant characteristics will be compared between the Film and VR groups using chi-square tests for the categorical characteristics (i.e., marital status) and t-tests for the continuous characteristics (i.e., age). Any characteristics that are significantly different between the VR and Film groups will be entered as a covariate in the main analyses to control for these differences.

Effort Over Time: Assessing for a main effect of trial number.  
Test: 2-level MLM with a fixed slope and random intercept.
Effort Model: SDMT Score ~ Cognitive Trials + (1|Participant)
DV: SDMT Score
IV: Cognitive Trials
Random Intercept: Participant
If there is a significant decrease in performance over trials, suggested by a main effect of trial number, this variable will be entered as a covariate in the main analyses to control for effort.

Expectancy Violation: Assessing for a main effect of Video Group.
Test: 2-level MLM with a fixed slope and random intercept.
Expectancy Model: Expectancy Violation Score ~ Video Group + (1|Participant)
DV: Expectancy Violation Score
IV: Video Group
Random Intercept: Participant
If there is a significant difference between Video Group (VR vs. Flat film), suggested by a main effect of Video Group, this variable will be entered as a covariate in the main analyses to control for this difference. 

Assumptions: Assumptions for each of the MLMs will be tested. Linearity will be investigated through visual inspection of a plot of the model residuals vs. the predictor. Homogeneity of variance will be investigated through the Levene’s test and through visual inspection of the residual vs. fitted value plots. Normally distributed residuals will be investigated through a visual inspection of Q-Q plots and histogram of the residuals. Lastly, influential cases/outliers will be identified by calculating cook’s distance for each model. If assumptions are violated, transformations will be conducted only if violations are extreme and results will be reported with the caveat that assumptions are violated.

To test for sufficient clustering, each of the baseline multilevel models (MLM) for the hypotheses will be conducted and the design effect (DEFF) calculated.
H1a, H2a, and H4 Baseline Model = Subjective Valence ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Subjective Valence 
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
H1b, H2b, and H4 Baseline Model = Subjective Arousal ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Subjective Arousal
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
H3 and H4 Baseline Model = Subjective Presence ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Subjective Presence
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Assessment of effort baseline model = SDMT Score ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = SDMT Score
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Expectancy violation baseline model = Expectancy Violation Score ~ 1 + (1|Participant)
DV = Expectancy Violation Score
IV = none
Random Intercept = Participant

attributes.title: Buffering Factors in Psychological Distress During Social Movement

q1.value: The effect of stressful life events on psychological well-being and possible buffering factors

q3.value: The goal of the present study is to investigate the impact of the involvement of social movement predicts subsequent psychological distress during the Anti-Extradition Law Amendment Bill (ELAB) Movement in Hong Kong. Hence, the extent of the internal resources (the trait of forgiveness, open-mindedness, and mindfulness) and the external resources provided by parent (perceived parental autonomy support, mutually trusting relationship, mutually listening behavior and basic psychological needs) of buffering the psychological distress during social movement in Hong Kong.

q4.value:
Based on current literature, we predict that, 
(1) The involvement of social movement is positively related to psychological distress.
(2) The internal resources act as the moderators which weaken the positive relationship of social movement involvement on psychological distress.
(3) The external resources act as the moderators which weaken the positive relationship of social movement involvement on psychological distress.
(4) The moderating effect which weakens the positive relationship of social movement involvement on the psychological distress of external resources depends on the levels of internal resources. 
(5) The discrepancy of parent-child affiliation will negatively predict the external resources, and hence negatively related to psychological distress.
(6) The discrepancy of parent-child affiliation will negatively predict the internal resources, and hence negatively related to psychological distress.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A correlational research design was utilized for this study. The goal of this study is to investigate the relationship between two predictors (the involvement of social movement and the discrepancy in parent-child political affiliation) and a criterion (psychological distress). And, the mediating and moderating effects of internal resources (forgiveness, open-mindedness, and mindfulness) and external resources (perceived parental autonomy support, mutually trusting relationship, mutually listening behavior, basic psychological needs) are going to investigate.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 166 participants will be recruited through online recruitment by sending WhatsApp message and mass e-mail to the university students. All participants recruited are aged 18-25 undergraduate students and living in Hong Kong over the past nine months. Participants’ self-reported histories of psychiatric or neurological conditions and present cognitive impairments are excluded after filling out the first part of the questionnaire. After confirmed the potential participants’ eligibility, participants will start to do the online questionnaire. Upon completion of time, participants will receive HK$20 as compensation.

q13.value: At least 166 participants will be recruited. While considering that some of the participants may not meet the requirements of this study, we will attempt to collect around 220 participants.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a small effect size of .10 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when we recruited 220 participants. Or the study will be ended at 22/4 the thesis submission date.

question.value:
This study contains two predictors, they are the involvement of the Anti-ELAB Movement and the discrepancy of the parent-child political affiliation. The involvement of the Anti-ELAB Movement will be measured by asking how much they support the movement, actual physical involvement, psychological involvement and time involved. Participants need to rate how much the statements represent them. The discrepancy of the parent-child political affiliation will be measured on a 7-point scale, by asking “How similar is the political affiliation between you and your parent(s)?”.

The criterion of psychological distress was assessed using the Kessler Psychological Distress Scale (K10), which is a 10-item questionnaire intended to measure adults’ distress level based on questions about the frequency and severity of depression and anxiety-related symptoms that a person has experienced over the past nine months. Participants use a 5‐point scale (1= “never” to 5 = “all the time”) to reflect on how they felt over the past nine months.

This study is testing seven mediators or moderatos: 

Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS)
Using the Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS) to measure parental autonomy support, initially developed for college students. The P-PASS is a 24-question scale to measure autonomy-supportive and controlling parenting behaviors using separate subscales.

The Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale-Revised (CAMS-R)
Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale-Revised (CAMS-R) is containing 12 items, aimed to detect a full range conceptualization of mindfulness. Participants rate how much the statements apply to them on the 4-point scale.

Heartland Forgiveness Scale (HFS) 
The Heartland Forgiveness Scale (HFS) is an 18-item questionnaire designed to access individual’s dispositional forgiveness. HFS has three 6-item measures of forgiveness of self, others, and situations. Participants rate each item on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = almost always false of me to 7 = almost always true of me. 

Actively open-minded thinking 17 (AOT17) 
Actively open-minded thinking 17 (AOT17) is measuring individual’s thinking styles. It was designed to assess individual’s tendency to engage in flexible or open-minded thinking. The scale contains 17 statements, which are rated on a 6-point scale (1=“strongly disagree” to 6=“strongly agree”). 

Listening scale
The listening scale is a 10-item questionnaire designed to access individuals’ willingness to listen to their parents and their perception of their parents’ willingness to listen to them. Participants rate each item on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = Strongly disagree to 7 = Strongly agree. 

Trust scale
Trustfulness scale is a 10-item questionnaire designed to access individuals’ trustfulness towards their parents and rate their perception of how their parents trust them in decision making. Participants rate each item on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = not at all to 6 = extremely. 

Basic Psychological Needs Scale
The basic Psychological needs scale is a 6-item questionnaire designed to access individuals’ basic psychological needs, including autonomy, competence, and relatedness. Participants rate each item on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = not at all true to 6 = very true.

The involvement of Anti-ELAB Movement
We will take the average score on the three items about participants' actual physical involvement, psychological involvement and time involved to measure the involvement of the Anti-ELAB Movement. 

The discrepancy of the parent-child political affiliation
The average score of the item “How similar is the political affiliation between you and your parent(s)?” will be calculated as the discrepancy of the parent-child political affiliation.

Kessler Psychological Distress Scale (K10)
None of the time represents 1 score, a little of the time represents 2 scores, some of the time represents 3 scores, most of the time represent 4 scores, all of the time means 5 scores. 
The average scores of 10 items will be calculated.   

Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS)
Items 1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 9, 13, 14, 16, 19, 23, 24 represent the extent of perceived autonomy support. The average score of all items will be calculated, participants with higher scores on these questions indicating higher levels of perception of autonomy support from parents. Items 3, 5, 6, 10, 11, 12, 15, 17, 18, 20, 21, and 22 represent the extent of psychological control. The average score of all items will be calculated, participants with higher scores on these questions indicating higher levels of perception of psychological control from parents. 

The Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale-Revised (CAMS-R)
Items 2, 6, and 7 are reverse scored. After reversing the items, average values for items 1 to 12. Higher values reflect greater mindful qualities.

Heartland Forgiveness Scale (HFS)
Almost always false of me represents 1 score, usually not true of me represent 2 scores, more often false of me represents 3 scores, occasionally true of me represents 4 scores, more often true of me represents 5 scores, usually true of me represents 6 scores, and almost always true of me represents 7 scores.
Scores for items 2, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, and 17 are reversed. Average the values for the items. 

Actively open-minded thinking 17 (AOT17) 
Items 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 13, 14, 15, and 17 are reverse scored. After reversing the items and calculating the average scores. Participants with higher scores indicate greater open-mindedness.

Listening scale
We will calculate the average scores of the first 5 items. In the first part of the scale, higher scores represent their parents are more willing to listen to them. And, we will calculate the average score of the last 5 items. In the last part of the scale, higher scores represent individuals who are more willing to listen to their parents.

Trust scale
We will calculate the average scores from the first 5 items. Higher scores in the first part of the scale represent individuals who are more willing to trust their parents. We will calculate the average score from the last 5 items. Higher scores in the second part of the scale represent their parents who are more willing to trust them.

Basic Psychological Needs Scale
We will calculate the average scores of 6 items and the total score is the score on this scale. Participants with higher scores indicate greater basic psychological needs, including autonomy, competence, and relatedness.

We will use multiple regression models and PROCESS to analyze the relationship between predictors (the involvement of social movement and the discrepancy of parent-child affiliation), criterion (psychological distress) and a set of meditators and moderates will be analyzed.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria and 95% confidence interval for determining the regression models, moderation models and mediation models.

q22.value:
First, the requirements of the participants will be listed in the online advertising and information sheet. All participants recruited are aged 18-25 undergraduate students and living in Hong Kong over the past nine months. Participants’ self-reported histories of psychiatric or neurological conditions and present cognitive impairments are excluded. Participants who cannot meet the requirements will be excluded after filling the first part of the questionnaire. 
Second, three attention check questions were used in this questionnaire, in order to filter out the careless respondents. If participants fail two out of three attention check questions, their data will be excluded. 
Third, if the questionnaires are not completed by the participants, they will be excluded as well.

q24.value: We will look for the moderation of the mediating effect.
