attributes.title: Feasibility and Enjoyment of Exergames (FLEX) Study

q1.value: Feasibility and Enjoyment of Exergames (FLEX) Study

q2.value: SARA ANN FREED, Briana N. Sprague, Lesley Ross

q3.value: The FLEX study was designed to address five main research questions. Before exposure, we are interested in the following two questions: (1) Do older adults believe exergames have the potential to improve cognitive abilities, and (2) What are older adults’ perceived barriers to physical exercise? After exposure, we are interested in the following questions: (3) Do older adults rate exergames more favorably for the potential to improve cognitive abilities after exergame exposure? (4) Does exposure to an exergame change one’s view of physical activity barriers? And (5) How do older adults rate enjoyment of exergames and what characteristics are related to greater enjoyment?

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1 (Descriptive): Before exergame exposure, older adults will report neutral or negative beliefs on whether exergames have the potential to improve cognitive abilities. 

Hypothesis 2 (Descriptive): Older adults will report the following barriers to physical exercise: enjoyment, access, cost, injury risk, space.  

Hypothesis 3 (Directional): After exergame exposure, older adults will report more stronger positive beliefs for the potential to improve cognitive abilities. 

Hypothesis 4 (Directional): After exergame exposure, older adults will report that exergames 
have the potential to address existing barriers to physical activity reported before exergame exposure, including enjoyment, access, cost, injury risk, and space.

Hypothesis 5 (Exploratory): Enjoyment of exergames will be explored by participant characteristics including age, gender, education, previous technology experience, and current level of physical activity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Mixed design: Both between- and within-person differences (See Sampling Plan for more detailed information on study design)

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data collection was completed on February 21, 2020 and data entry is currently ongoing. S. Freed collected data and B. Sprague and L. Ross have not seen any participant data prior to preregistration.  No  statistics have been conducted and data analysis will not commence prior to preregistering the main research questions and analytic plan.

question.value:
The following data collection procedures have been approved by the Penn State Institutional Review Board STUDY00012424. Please see study flow diagram which shows how participants move through the study and how participation will be tracked.

The sample for this study will be 20 healthy community-dwelling older adults between the ages of 65 and 85 who are able and willing to do moderate to vigorous physical activity. Participants will be recruited from flyers posted in community spaces including coffee shops and senior centers as well as a database of older adults interested in being contacted for research studies.  Participants will undergo a brief (15 minute) telephone screener. If they are eligible (see exclusion criteria below), they will be scheduled for a one-time in-person visit lasting approximately 75 minutes. In between the telephone screener and in-person visit, they will complete a take home packet that takes about 30 minutes to complete. 

The study visit will consist of surveys and questionnaires, use of an exergame, followed by additional questionnaires and interviews. The in-person visit is expected to take around 75 minutes total. After the completion of the surveys, the participant will play the exergame for about 30 minutes. Participants will play Kinect Adventures and Just Dance on an Xbox Kinect. After the completion of the exergame, the study staff will do a debriefing and semi-structured feedback survey with the participant. It is expected that this will take approximately 30 minutes. At the end of the study, participants will be compensated $10. 

Exclusion criteria: residing in a nursing home or other institution, older than 85 or younger than 65 years of age, no English language proficiency, participation in organized exercise program for more than two hours/week in past 2 years, video game console use for more than two hours/week in past 2 years, use of walker, cane, and/or wheelchair, more than 2 falls in the past 2 months, Parkinson's disease or other motor diseases, uncontrolled asthma, COPD, peripheral neuropathy, diabetes, cardiac disease, or hypertension, history of traumatic brain injury, advised by medical professional to not do moderate to vigorous physical activity, and <= 4 score on Einstein Aging Study Telephone Screener delayed recall (indicating memory impairment).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 20 older adult participants.

q14.value: 20 participants will be examined in this pilot study. The sample size was determined by budgetary constraints and to serve as a pilot study.

question.value: All participants completed the exergame training protocol. Games included Just Dance and Kinect Adventures. The order of games was counterbalanced.

The following is a list of all measures that will be administered in the study. Please see attachment for in-lab protocol cover sheet. 

TELEPHONE SCREENING
Demographics (Race/Ethnicity, Gender, Age, Education)
Current Physical Activity
Memory Impairment Telephone Screener (Immediate Recall)
Health Conditions and Eligibility 
Memory Impairment Telephone Screener (Delayed Recall)

TAKE-HOME QUESTIONNAIRE
Mobile Device Proficiency Questionnaire (MDPQ-16)
Video Game Experience Questionnaire
Expectations Regarding Aging (ERA)
Physical Activity Enjoyment Scale (PAES)
Expectations about Cognitive Health 
Expectations of Exergames (Pretest)
Barriers to Being Active
Fear of Falling Inventory
Ryff’s Psychological Well-Being Scale [Purpose in Life Subscale]
Transportation Questionnaire 
Technology Use Questionnaire 

IN-LAB PRETEST
Eligibility Review
Big Five Inventory, 44-item
Rapid Assessment of Physical Activity (RAPA)
MOS Short Form-36 (SF-36)
Florida Cognitive Activities Scale (FCAS)
Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)

IN-LAB POSTTEST
Borg Perceived Exertion 
(Primary outcome) Expectations of Exergames (Posttest)
(Primary outcome) Barriers to Exergames  
(Primary outcome) Enjoyment of Program

Some of the questionnaires that will be used in the study have standardized composite score calculations. We will use published guidelines to calculate composite scores where applicable though we may also use individual items for specific research questions. Composite scores will be calculated for the following questionnaires/measures: Mobile Device Proficiency Questionnaire (MDPQ-16), Video Game Experience Questionnaire, Physical Activity Enjoyment Scale (PAES), Expectations of Exergames, Barriers to Being Active, Fear of Falling Inventory, Ryff's Psychological Well-Being Scale [Purpose in Life Subscale], Big Five Inventory 44-item, Rapid Assessment of Physical Activity (RAPA), MOS Short Form-36 (SF-36), Florida Cognitive Activities Scale (FCAS), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA).

Aim 1 (Descriptive): To conduct this descriptive aim, we will calculate means and standard deviations of individual items and composite scores for the Expectations about Exergames questionnaire administered before exergame exposure.

Aim 2 (Descriptive): To conduct this descriptive aim, we will calculate means and standard deviations of individual items and composite scores for the Barriers to Being Active measure. Pairwise comparisons will be used to determine statistical significance of the differences between barriers. For example, are ratings of access as a barrier significantly higher than cost as a barrier?  

Aim 3 (Directional): We will use paired samples t-tests to examine differences in the pre-exposure to post-exposure scores. We may also use a difference score as an outcome variable to determine predictors of increased positive beliefs that exergames will improve cognition as an exploratory outcome. 

Aim 4 (Directional): We will primarily use qualitative data for this aim in conjunction with descriptives (means, standard deviations) of the exergame-specific barriers to exercise questions in the post-exposure assessment.

Aim 5 (Exploratory): We will use correlations to identify the most promising predictors of exergame enjoyment, considering age, gender, education, previous technology experience, and current level of physical activity. We will include the most promising predictors in a regression model predicting exergame enjoyment. We will also report written qualitative feedback from participants as part of this aim.

q20.value: Subscales of certain measures (e.g., physical function subscale of the MOS SF-36) will be calculated according to the original reference instructions. Any interaction effect models will be analyzed using mean centered variables.

q21.value: Significance will be evaluated at p < .05 for two-tailed tests. Given the exploratory nature of the pilot project, analyses will not correct for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
All participants with eligible data will be analyzed. Eligible participants include any who completed the research protocol through the posttest assessment. 

Scores that are likely influential outliers will be rescald using windsorizing. The score will be rescaled so that it is 2 SD in the direction of their score. For example, if a participant had an extremely high value on an item, the score will be rescaled to be +2SD above mean value.

q23.value:
All precautions will be taken to ensure that all data are complete. However, in instances where there are missing data, missing values will be imputed using multiple imputation.

registration_responses.q1: Feasibility and Enjoyment of Exergames (FLEX) Study
registration_responses.q2: SARA ANN FREED, Briana N. Sprague, Lesley Ross
registration_responses.q3: The FLEX study was designed to address five main research questions. Before exposure, we are interested in the following two questions: (1) Do older adults believe exergames have the potential to improve cognitive abilities, and (2) What are older adults’ perceived barriers to physical exercise? After exposure, we are interested in the following questions: (3) Do older adults rate exergames more favorably for the potential to improve cognitive abilities after exergame exposure? (4) Does exposure to an exergame change one’s view of physical activity barriers? And (5) How do older adults rate enjoyment of exergames and what characteristics are related to greater enjoyment?
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1 (Descriptive): Before exergame exposure, older adults will report neutral or negative beliefs on whether exergames have the potential to improve cognitive abilities. 

Hypothesis 2 (Descriptive): Older adults will report the following barriers to physical exercise: enjoyment, access, cost, injury risk, space.  

Hypothesis 3 (Directional): After exergame exposure, older adults will report more stronger positive beliefs for the potential to improve cognitive abilities. 

Hypothesis 4 (Directional): After exergame exposure, older adults will report that exergames 
have the potential to address existing barriers to physical activity reported before exergame exposure, including enjoyment, access, cost, injury risk, and space.

Hypothesis 5 (Exploratory): Enjoyment of exergames will be explored by participant characteristics including age, gender, education, previous technology experience, and current level of physical activity.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question: Mixed design: Both between- and within-person differences (See Sampling Plan for more detailed information on study design)
registration_responses.q12.question:
The following data collection procedures have been approved by the Penn State Institutional Review Board STUDY00012424. Please see study flow diagram which shows how participants move through the study and how participation will be tracked.

The sample for this study will be 20 healthy community-dwelling older adults between the ages of 65 and 85 who are able and willing to do moderate to vigorous physical activity. Participants will be recruited from flyers posted in community spaces including coffee shops and senior centers as well as a database of older adults interested in being contacted for research studies.  Participants will undergo a brief (15 minute) telephone screener. If they are eligible (see exclusion criteria below), they will be scheduled for a one-time in-person visit lasting approximately 75 minutes. In between the telephone screener and in-person visit, they will complete a take home packet that takes about 30 minutes to complete. 

The study visit will consist of surveys and questionnaires, use of an exergame, followed by additional questionnaires and interviews. The in-person visit is expected to take around 75 minutes total. After the completion of the surveys, the participant will play the exergame for about 30 minutes. Participants will play Kinect Adventures and Just Dance on an Xbox Kinect. After the completion of the exergame, the study staff will do a debriefing and semi-structured feedback survey with the participant. It is expected that this will take approximately 30 minutes. At the end of the study, participants will be compensated $10. 

Exclusion criteria: residing in a nursing home or other institution, older than 85 or younger than 65 years of age, no English language proficiency, participation in organized exercise program for more than two hours/week in past 2 years, video game console use for more than two hours/week in past 2 years, use of walker, cane, and/or wheelchair, more than 2 falls in the past 2 months, Parkinson's disease or other motor diseases, uncontrolled asthma, COPD, peripheral neuropathy, diabetes, cardiac disease, or hypertension, history of traumatic brain injury, advised by medical professional to not do moderate to vigorous physical activity, and <= 4 score on Einstein Aging Study Telephone Screener delayed recall (indicating memory impairment).
registration_responses.q16.question: All participants completed the exergame training protocol. Games included Just Dance and Kinect Adventures. The order of games was counterbalanced.

attributes.title: Childhood Maltreatment, Identity and Self-identity Recognition

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Childhood Maltreatment, Identity and Self-identity Recognition

sample.value: We aim to recruit a sample of 100 university students

analyses.value: In order to test these hypotheses, we will calculate the percentages of exposure to childhood maltreatment among participants and will divide them into two groups, with and without CM histories. Then, we will calculate the levels of accuracy in the identity and self-identity recognition tasks and will compare the mean scores between these groups. Furthermore, we will calculate the percentage of negative and positive self-referential words in each group and will examine the association between the performance in the SRET task and the identity and self-identity recognition tasks, separately in each group.

outliers.value: fail more than one of the eight attention-check questions

dependent.value:
self-identity recognition - morphing process 
Self-Referential Encoding Task (SRET; Derry & Kuiper, 1981)

conditions.value: We aim to recruit a sample of 100 university students. The inclusion criteria are being English-speaking, and 18 years of age or older. Participants will be excluded if they fail more than one of the eight attention-check questions which were interspersed throughout the questionnaire battery.

hypothesis.value: (1) lower performances in self-identity recognition task will be found among individuals with CM histories, compared to those with no CM histories; (2) higher frequencies of negative self-referential words will be found in the CM group, compared to the non-CM group; (3) higher levels of negative self-referential perception will be associated with lower performance in the self-identity recognition task.
